mdx: # Avatar A small image or icon that identifies and personalizes the user within the interface. ## Overview Avatar components can include images or the initials of the user’s first and last name. ### Resources Deep dive into implementation details and access the Nimbus design library. [Figma library](https://www.figma.com/design/AvtPX6g7OGGCRvNlatGOIY/NIMBUS-design-system?node-id=346-2611&t=WljaKGkdJ1dZn3oM-4) ## Variables Get familiar with the features. ### Size **Medium** (40px) Most commonly used in the upper right hand side of the page paired with a drop-down menu. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( {/* Shows initials when no image */} ) ``` **X-Small** (32px) Use small circle avatars in tighter areas like text fields and dropdown fields or when it is less important information. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( {/* Shows initials when no image */} ) ``` **2x-Small** (24px) Use these in condensed areas like notifications or filters. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( {/* Shows initials when no image */} ) ``` ### Initials and images #### Avatar initials The default and fallback for avatar graphics is to use initials. Default color should use Primary, but is open to custom colors. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( ) ``` ## Specs ## Accessibility The Avatar component is a thumbnail representation of an entity, such as a user or an organization. They accept a `src` attribute defining the image URL, and an `alt` attribute for an accessible description. ```jsx-live const App = () => ( ) ``` ### Accessibility standards #### 1. Perceivable: - **1.1.1 Non-text Content (Level A):** This is the most crucial guideline for avatars. Since avatars are visual, they must have a text alternative. This is typically implemented using the alt attribute on the `` tag (if the avatar is an image) or through `ARIA` if the avatar is more complex. The alt text should describe the avatar's purpose or what it represents (e.g., "User profile picture," "John Doe's avatar," "Company logo"). If the avatar is purely decorative and doesn't convey any meaningful information, the alt attribute should be empty (`alt=""`). - **1.3.1 Info and Relationships (Level A):** If the avatar is associated with other information (e.g., a username, profile link), the relationship should be programmatically determinable. This can be achieved using semantic `HTML` (e.g., placing the avatar and username within a single element) or ARIA attributes (e.g., `aria-labelledby` or `aria-describedby`). - **1.4.1 Use of Color (Level A):** Don't rely on color alone to convey information about the avatar (e.g., using a colored border to indicate status). Any information conveyed by color must also be available through other means. - **1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum) (Level AA):** If the avatar contains any text (which is less common), that text must meet minimum contrast ratio requirements. #### 2. Operable: - **2.1.1 Keyboard (Level A):** If the avatar is interactive (e.g., clicking it opens a profile), it must be operable using the keyboard. This means the user should be able to navigate to the avatar using the Tab key and activate it using the Enter or Space key. - **2.4.4 Link Purpose (In Context) (Level A):** If the avatar is a link, its purpose should be clear from the surrounding context or from the avatar's alt text. Avoid generic link text like "Click here." - **2.4.7 Focus Visible (Level AA):** If the avatar is interactive, it should have a visible focus indicator when it receives keyboard focus. #### 3. Understandable: - **3.2.1 On Focus (Level A):** If the avatar is interactive and its appearance changes on focus, the change should not be disorienting or unexpected. #### 4. Robust: - **4.1.2 Name, Role, Value (Level A):** Assistive technologies should be able to correctly interpret the role of the avatar (e.g., `image`, `link`) and its name (from the alt text).
